sections.title: Creating customised advertising

inlineContent.text: In this tutorial, we will learn how to create custom ads using AdSDK. This process is the same for both inline and interstitial ads.
We will continue to build the app, so be sure to follow all the previous tutorials. You can download
which has already implemented all steps from this tutorial.
In this tutorial, we want to display a picture and frame it, but in real-world projects, your ad can be anything - video, HTML, graphics, etc.

sections.chapter: Extending the SDK with your custom advertisements

inlineContent.text: When creating custom ads, we always separate business logic and state management from presentation logic. Let’s start by creating business logic using the
The server should always be configured to return a custom response when using custom advertising. In this tutorial, the server is configured to give us the following response.

model that we will use.
Since the renderer is an extension to the SDK, it should also work only with the
error type. Create a

You can also use
to throw specific errors related to your renderer to the app.
In this file, we will add the ability to decode JSON with automatic conversion of any
type to the

Let’s return to
We use the
interface to control the business logic and ad state. You can think of it as the View Model of your ad.
The first step is to implement
. It is used by the SDK to create an
with
passing. We’ll look at what
is later. For now, just save the reference to the property.
The
can implement another initializer, which we will also look at later.
The next thing we add is the
method. This method is the key to creating ads. Within it, you have to perform all the logic to prepare the ad for display - decoding, additional downloads, etc.
This method is directly related to the
and
methods. As soon as this method is completed, the
will be returned to the app.
The
parameter contains the entire response from the server. Let’s add the decoding logic to get the data we need to create the ad.
The next step is to load a banner for display. This is what we use
for. It can download, cache, and return cached advertising resources. When using it, we don’t need to think about caching, as the whole process takes place internally. Isn’t it convenient?
can finish with an
, in which case creating or reloading an ad will end with this error, or return you
. From it, we can get the loaded data and find out whether it was successfully cached.
In addition, the method has a
parameter. This
will be available in the app, and you can use it to pass some additional information from the renderer to the app.
If you use interactive elements in the upper right corner of your banner,
may also be useful for you. If this value is true, you should reserve 18 pt for this button.
We’ve decoded the data we need and retrieved the ad banner, which means it’s time to change the state of our controller so that the future
knows it can display this content.
In addition, the
has another optional

method. In it, you can implement logic to clear your state and prepare for a reload. In our case, it’s not very useful, but it can come in handy, for example, if your renderer uses a timer or another process that you would like to terminate.
In the previous section, we implemented the logic associated with loading and reloading your custom ad. The next step will be to implement the processing of ad-related events.
Let’s continue working with our
. Almost all ads need to handle taps, but our controller doesn’t have this functionality at the moment.
You should keep a weak reference to this object. Otherwise, you may have memory issues.
In order to execute or notify about an event, we use
. In fact, it is an
object that knows how to handle certain events.
If an error occurs when processing an event, you should not attempt to repeat it, as this is the responsibility of the app, which can do so using
. You can use this error to debug or change the state of the presentation.
Now we can implement the method that will be called when the banner is tapped.
The tap event is not the only event that
can handle. You can find all events in the
documentation.
Even though our business layer is ready, we still can’t build our project. That’s because the SDK requires a presentation layer. Let’s implement it with
Let’s continue our development in the same file.
If the
is the business layer of our custom ad and is part of the
life cycle, then the
is the presentation layer and part of the
or
hierarchy. Let’s create a
as a
and
protocols. It will contain our presentation logic.
The only thing the
protocol requires is an init with a specific type of
The last step to build our project is to add a renderer type to the controller. We can use typealias to do this. Now we can build the project.
The final touch will be to create our
body, where we display the image with a border when it is loaded and call the
method when the user taps it.

tasks.title: Registering a renderer in the SDK

inlineContent.text: Although we have created a custom ad, in order for the SDK to use it, we need to pass it to the SDK somehow. Let’s do that.
First of all, let’s get back to our response from the server. As you can see, it includes the
field. It is this field that the SDK will use to identify your renderer.
Let’s go to the
file, the place where we create our
. This is where we will be able to register our custom renderer.
All we need to do is use the
method, passing in the value we expect to receive in the
field and the renderer type. This way, every time the
field in the server response is the same as the
you passed to this method, the SDK will display the
Open the
file and pay attention to the
method.
We will add an additional
that will deliver our new type of ad. Now you can launch the app and see your new custom ad, congratulations!
Our ad can already load and cache an ad banner via

, but there are cases when you want to implement more flexible caching logic, for example, you want to put several ad resources in one folder and use it as a base URL for your Web View. In this section, we will look at how to do this.
Return to the
file.
One of the initializer must be implemented, otherwise you will get an
error. In addition, if both initializers are implemented,
will have higher priority.
As we said earlier, the
can implement another initializer
. Let’s implement it.
This initialiser receives the
object, which is an interface for working with the cache, and the
object, which can be used to conveniently load ad resources. Save the references to these objects in properties.
Comment out the logic for working with
in the
method, and create a new
method. We will implement our own loading and caching logic in it.
When passing the URL to
, the
will use the MD5 hash of the passed URL as the filename.
The first thing we will create is
. In our case, we want the file name to be associated with the URL, and this resource is located in the
folder.
Now we can check if our banner is cached via
, if so, we will use the cached data.
If not, we can download the banner using
Since the banner has already been uploaded, we would like to cache it for future use. To do this, you can use the
method. Congratulations, we have implemented our own caching and loading logic!
Most often, you do not need to remove resources manually, as the SDK itself manages the removal of files from the cache using a FIFO strategy and a cache size that is set from the app.
You can also remove files from the cache if you need to. Congratulations, we have implemented our own caching and loading logic!
